title: Which team will win the Men's International Cricket Council (ICC) Cricket World Cup 2019?
preds: England in better form and have the home advantage

Updating...
• AUS: 33 → 28 off the back of an OK effort but still a loss to RSA. Also puts them in a semi with ENG
• IND: 30 → 36 also not a strong last group match, but a semi against NZ makes a final spot very likely
• ENG: 26 → 28 due to not having to win a semi against India, AUS will be an easier win (and AUS vs ENG in ENG are prone to collapses) - but never having won a world cup will always weigh heavy on them
• NZ 12 → 8 due to semi against India. However if they can win that they'll be taking some serious momentum in to the final.

- Consideration of WC19 results so far (table + wins/losses), and considering the momentum they are taking in (e.g. England have bounced back).
- Based on semis of AU vs NZ, ENG vs IND. 
- Consideration of WC's won so far, which has a "choking" factor (e.g. South Africa)
- Consideration of pitch wear, which as the tournament goes on is favouring spinners (weights towards IND and AUS playing on more familiar pitches)
- Consideration of weather over the past week, and forecasts for semis and finals (IND vs ENG semi is overcast - slightly suiting ENG)
- Some consideration of ICC rankings and aggregated odds, and home team factor (not huge in cricket)

England have been looking good and have home advantage. Australia will out perform expectations and format favours consistently good teams - less chance of a lucky result winning the tournament.

I predict that Australia will win the 2019 Cricket World Cup. They have a 30% chance of winning because they have won 5 out of 11 World Cups and have been runner-up in 2 of them despite being 5th in ODI team rankings. While England leads in ODI Team Rankings, some analysts predict that England does not have as strong of a team as some of the others and may make unnecessary mistakes during competition. In addition, England has never won the Cricket World Cup. India is 2nd in ODI team rankings and also has a strong team in addition to winning 2 of the past Cricket World Cups, but I've seen articles stating that they have some serious weaknesses. New Zealand has not won the Cricket World Cup, but has some strong team members and may eke out some surprise victories. The West Indies won the first 2 Cricket World Cups and are also a possible underdog. The other teams could win, but it is extremely unlikely.

My rankings are based off a combination of historic performance, current performance, and admittedly, personal preference.  Pakistan and India are cricket heavyweights, and in a tournament format I think they have the institutional knowledge and experience to perform well.  South Africa has a solid squad that I think a lot of normal cricket powerhouses could be upset by.

I put India at 55% likelihood at winning the Cricket World Cup in 2019 because of their top ranking in the ICC Test Championships which concluded last month, May 2019. India has also won two Cricket World Cups in the past making it credible that they could win again. I put Australia at 25% because although they have not been doing as well in the rankings prior to this years World Cup (ranking highest at 4th place in the ICC T201 Championship) they have won the most Cricket World Cups, a total of four wins therefore I think it is possible they could win this year. I put Pakistan at a 20% likelihood because they ranked first in the ICC T201 Championship last month, May 2019 and today, the first day of the World Cup, they beat England. Therefore, I also think it is possible Pakistan could win.

I'm definitely not an expert when it comes to cricket, so I'm really leaning heavily on the analysis of others. Looking at reports from BBC and the ICC, it seems England is the top contender to win due to a complete team overall following their early exit in 2015. Closely following them is India. South Africa, NZ, and Australia have good chances as well but roster changes have placed them at a disadvantage. Pakistan had a fairly good chance, but injuries combined with a fairly young team might rule them out. West Indies could be a dark horse, depending if they can continue to surprise.

There have been a total 11 ICC World Cup tournaments, since 1975 and the matches occur generally every four years.  Australia has won the title 5 times (has won the championship 45% of the time). Australia has additionally played in 7 of the 11 championship matches (loss ration of 28%). On the other hand, England has been to the final 3 times, however has not won it. The West Indies also won the ICC World Cup twice (has won the championship 18% of the time). As such, I believe that Australia has the biggest chance of winning the match because of its history of winning and near 33% of appearing in the final match). Even though the West Indies, Sri Lanka, and Pakistan have won the championship match, they have not done so since 1996. Australia has more recently won the cup consecutively, while India beat Sri Lanka in 2011. Afghanistan, Bangladesh and South Africa have never been in the final match. India and Sri Lanka have been traded off in regard to being in the final match recently, however Sri Lanka has not won the final match since 1996. 
For most of my percents, I calculated the number of times the country has been in the final match regardless if they won or not, and divided it by 24- representing the number of final matches, including the 2019 match.

There are other people who have made forecasts already who are a lot more knoweldgeable on Cricket.  A sport I have only played once in the desert of the United Arab Emirates.  I leaned heavily on the current cricket standings, the historical records, and the research of forecasters below to make my predictions, I_orage really seems to know what they are talking about.  This will be the first time I've ever made a sports related prediction not based on how I like the uniforms! (March Madness, thank you very much).

The Noise: England first:  364, 359, 341 - these have been England's score in the last three ODIs that they have played en route to which they not only decimated Pakistan to clinch a 3-0 win in the ongoing five-match series, the Eoin Morgan-led side also surpassed India's record by successfully chasing 340-plus totals four times in the history. England has grown to be a force to reckon with since their humiliating group-stage exit from the last World Cup at the hands of Bangladesh. Besides the home advantage, England has won all their previous 16 matches while chasing targets. In fact, they have the highest win percentage - 65.51 - since World Cup 2015. India second... A strong top-order pair, the formidable MS Dhoni factor in the middle-order and a daunting seam-bowling attack are what brings pride to the Indian cricket team. However, their inability to yet specify the No.4 batsman along with their middle-order conundrum in the recent past keep the Indians at the second spot. Besides, the Men in Blue were recently outclassed by Steve Smith and David Warner-less Australian side at home. Statistically, India stands second with 65.11 percent win since the last World Cup.  Source: www.timesnownews.com/sports/cricket/article/icc-cricket-world-cup-2019-prediction-who-will-win-the-showpiece-tournament/421366 As per the survey, England earned 41.23 percent of the votes, which makes them overpowering top choices. India's most despised adversaries Pakistan (25.37 percent), who have been in flawless in the shorter configuration of the diversion (ODI) are at the second top choices to win the world title.   This is a possibility, though a long shot based on research. Source: https://sites.google.com/site/cwc2019todaymatchprediction/ Betters favor England: England (+200 to win)
England stands as the favorites to win this tournament, even though the nation’s best finish as an ICC World Cup host is a runner-up finish (in 1979). England’s standing as the outright favorites on the futures list is backed by the fact that June 2017 marks the nation’s last ODI series defeat.
Flat pitches, which provide lower levels of bounce and lateral motion, are where England thrive best, with those types of surfaces affording them greater license to focus on their main game plan, which is to outscore the opposition. India (+300)
Despite losing the crown in 2015, India has gone from strength to strength. In the build-up to this World Cup in England, they have beaten every major rival in at least one series. Although 2019 has brought mixed results for the Indian team, they boast one of the best captains around with Virat Kohli on course to break several international records.
India stands as second favorites to England in the long list, but not by a considerable distance. Source: https://www.thelines.com/odds/cricket-world-cup/ The Facts: ASSESSED BEST PLAYERS IN THE 2019 CRICKET WORLD CUP Of the top 3 batsmen: India #1
Of the top 3 bowlers: India #1
Of the top 3 all-rounders: India #1
Of the top 3 wicket-keeper batsman: India #1 Bottom Line- the best players in each position are all from India.
PAK is a favored show, as is AU, SA, and NZ.  PAK and AUS have challenging schedules in regular matches- and NZ remains a contender based on national pride following the Christchurch massacre.  In the qualifying rounds for the 2014 FIFA World Cup, Iceland reached the playoffs before losing to Croatia. Iceland reached its first major tournament, UEFA Euro 2016 after a qualification campaign which included home and away wins over the Netherlands. In doing so, they became the smallest ever nation to qualify for a major tournament.  No one saw this coming… so a similar run remains possible for NZ. Source: https://www.thelines.com/odds/cricket-world-cup/ England has appeared in every edition of the Cricket World Cup to date. They have never won the competition, but their best performances were losing finalists in 1979, 1987 and 1992; they have also been eliminated in the Group stage of the competitions on 3 occasions: 1999, 2003 and 2015. England has hosted the World Cup more than any other team, 4 times in total, including the first 3 World Cups in 1975, 1979 and 1983. They are also scheduled to host the 2019 Cricket World Cup, from 30 May to 15 July 2019.  While England are much improved after issues that led to their group-stage elimination in 2015, the fact remains that England has only ever finished as runners up on home turf.

I have never watched a second of cricket in my life so my forecast should be taken with a large grain of salt. I am most concerned about giving only a 10% chance to defending champion Australia. Bookmakers are favoring England, who is both the host country and the highest-ranked team in ODI cricket. England has broke the record for the ODI team total twice since 2015. India reached the 2017 ICC Champions final in 2017 and are ranked second in ODI cricket. Defending champion Australia has returned two stars that have been dealing with injury that should bring with them more offense. New Zealand made it to the final of the 2015 tournament and fields a very balanced team. South Africa recieved 5% odds because they are in one of the projected five most likely finals matchups.
